pyinterpolate.pipelines package#

Submodules#

pyinterpolate.pipelines.block_filtering module#

The Area-to-Area, Area-to-Point, Centroid-based Poisson Kriging.

Authors#

  1. Szymon Moli≈Ñski | @SimonMolinsky

class BlockPK(semivariogram_model: TheoreticalVariogram, blocks: Union[Blocks, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, ndarray], point_support: Union[Dict, ndarray, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, PointSupport], kriging_type='ata')[source]#

Bases: object

Class is an object that can be used for Area-to-Area, Area-to-Point, Centroid-based Poisson Kriging regularization.

Parameters:

  • semivariogram_model (TheoreticalVariogram) ‚Äì Fitted variogram model.

  • blocks (Union[Blocks, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, np.ndarray]) ‚Äì Blocks with aggregated data. * Blocks: Blocks() class object. * GeoDataFrame and DataFrame must have columns: centroid.x, centroid.y, ds, index.

    Geometry column with polygons is not used and optional.

    • numpy array: [[block index, centroid x, centroid y, value]].

  • point_support (Union[Dict, np.ndarray, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, PointSupport]) ‚Äì

    • Dict: {block id: [[point x, point y, value]]}

    • numpy array: [[block id, x, y, value]]

    • DataFrame and GeoDataFrame: columns={x, y, ds, index}

    • PointSupport

  • kriging_type (str, default=‚Äôata‚Äô) ‚Äì Poisson Kriging operation. Available methods: * ‚Äòata‚Äô: Area-to-Area Poisson Kriging. * ‚Äòatp‚Äô: Area-to-Point Poisson Kriging. * ‚Äòcb‚Äô: Centroid-based Poisson Kriging.

Variables:

  • semivariogram_model (TheoreticalVariogram) ‚Äì See semivariogram_model parameter.

  • blocks (Union[Blocks, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, np.ndarray]) ‚Äì See blocks parameter.

  • point_support (Union[Dict, np.ndarray, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, PointSupport]) ‚Äì See point_support parameter.

  • kriging_type (str, default='ata') ‚Äì See kriging_type parameter.

  • geo_ds (geopandas GeoDataFrame) ‚Äì Regularized set of blocks: [‚Äòid‚Äô, ‚Äògeometry‚Äô, ‚Äòreg.est‚Äô, ‚Äòreg.err‚Äô, ‚Äòrmse‚Äô]

  • statistics (Dict) ‚Äì ‚ÄòRMSE‚Äô: root mean squared error of regularization, ‚Äòtime‚Äô: time (in seconds) of the regularization process.

  • raise_when_negative_prediction (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction is negative.

  • raise_when_negative_error (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction error is negative.

regularize()[source]#

Regularize blocks (you should use it for data deconvolution - with ATP PK, or for data filtering - with ATA, C-B PK).

regularize(number_of_neighbors, data_crs=None, raise_when_negative_prediction=True, raise_when_negative_error=True)[source]#

Function regularizes whole dataset and creates new values and error maps based on the kriging type. Function does not predict unknown and missing values, areas with NaN are skipped.

Parameters:

  • number_of_neighbors (int) ‚Äì The minimum number of neighbours that potentially affect block.

  • data_crs (str, default=None) ‚Äì Data crs, look into: https://geopandas.org/projections.html. If None given then returned GeoDataFrame doesn‚Äôt have a crs.

  • raise_when_negative_prediction (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction is negative.

  • raise_when_negative_error (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction error is negative.

Returns:

regularized ‚Äì Regularized set of blocks: [‚Äòid‚Äô, ‚Äògeometry‚Äô, ‚Äòreg.est‚Äô, ‚Äòreg.err‚Äô, ‚Äòrmse‚Äô]

Return type:

gpd.GeoDataFrame

pyinterpolate.pipelines.deconvolution module#

Regularization: blocks to point support.

Authors#

  1. Szymon Moli≈Ñski | @SimonMolinsky

smooth_area_to_point_pk(semivariogram_model: TheoreticalVariogram, blocks: Union[Blocks, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, ndarray], point_support: Union[Dict, ndarray, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, PointSupport], number_of_neighbors: int, max_range=None, crs: Optional[Any] = None, raise_when_negative_prediction=True, raise_when_negative_error=True, err_to_nan=True) → GeoDataFrame[source]#

Function smooths blocks data into their point support values.

Parameters:

  • semivariogram_model (TheoreticalVariogram) ‚Äì Regularized variogram.

  • blocks (Union[Blocks, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, np.ndarray]) ‚Äì Blocks with aggregated data. * Blocks: Blocks() class object. * GeoDataFrame and DataFrame must have columns: centroid.x, centroid.y, ds, index.

    Geometry column with polygons is not used and optional.

    • numpy array: [[block index, centroid x, centroid y, value]].

  • point_support (Union[Dict, np.ndarray, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, PointSupport]) ‚Äì

    • Dict: {block id: [[point x, point y, value]]}

    • numpy array: [[block id, x, y, value]]

    • DataFrame and GeoDataFrame: columns={x, y, ds, index}

    • PointSupport

  • number_of_neighbors (int) ‚Äì The minimum number of neighbours that potentially affect block.

  • max_range (float, deault=None) ‚Äì The maximum distance to search for neighbors.

  • crs (Any, default=None) ‚Äì CRS of data.

  • raise_when_negative_prediction (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction is negative.

  • raise_when_negative_error (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction error is negative.

  • err_to_nan (bool, default=True) ‚Äì ValueError to NaN.

Returns:

results ‚Äì columns=[area_id, geometry (Point), prediction, error]

Return type:

gpd.GeoDataFrame

pyinterpolate.pipelines.multi_kriging module#

Block data interpolation with a different kriging techniques.

Authors#

  1. Szymon Moli≈Ñski | @SimonMolinsky

class BlockToBlockKrigingComparison(variogram: TheoreticalVariogram, blocks: Union[Blocks, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, ndarray], point_support: Union[Dict, ndarray, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, PointSupport], no_of_neighbors: int = 16, neighbors_range: Optional[float] = None, simple_kriging_mean: Optional[float] = None, raise_when_negative_prediction=True, raise_when_negative_error=True, training_set_frac=0.8, allow_approx_solutions=False, iters=20)[source]#

Bases: object

Class compares different block kriging models and techniques.

blocksUnion[Blocks, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, np.ndarray]

Blocks with aggregated data. * Blocks: Blocks() class object. * GeoDataFrame and DataFrame must have columns: centroid.x, centroid.y, ds, index.

Geometry column with polygons is not used and optional.

  • numpy array: [[block index, centroid x, centroid y, value]].

point_supportUnion[Dict, np.ndarray, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, PointSupport]

  • Dict: {block id: [[point x, point y, value]]}

  • numpy array: [[block id, x, y, value]]

  • DataFrame and GeoDataFrame: columns={x, y, ds, index}

  • PointSupport

no_of_neighborsint, default = 16

Maximum number of n-closest neighbors used for interpolation.

neighbors_rangefloat, default = None

Maximum distance where we search for point neighbors. If None given then range is selected from the theoretical_model rang attribute. If there is less neighbors than no_of_neighbors within the range then algorithm selects additional points outside the neighbors_range.

simple_kriging_meanfloat, default = None

The mean value of a process over a study area. Should be know before processing. If not provided then Simple Kriging estimator is skipped.

raise_when_negative_predictionbool, default = True

Raise error when prediction is negative.

raise_when_negative_errorbool, default=True

Raise error when prediction error is negative.

training_set_fracfloat, default = 0.8

How many values sampled as a known points set in each iteration. Could be any fraction within (0:1) range.

allow_approx_solutionsbool, default = False

Allows the approximation of kriging weights based on the OLS algorithm. Not recommended to set to True if you don‚Äôt know what you are doing!

itersint, default = 20

How many tests to perform over random samples of a data.

Variables:

  • variogram (TheoreticalVariogram) ‚Äì See variogram parameter.

  • blocks (Union[Blocks, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, np.ndarray]) ‚Äì See blocks parameter.

  • point_support (Union[Dict, np.ndarray, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, PointSupport]) ‚Äì See point_support parameter.

  • no_of_neighbors (int) ‚Äì See no_of_neighbors parameter.

  • neighbors_range (float) ‚Äì See neighbors_range parameter.

  • simple_kriging_mean (float) ‚Äì See simple_kriging_mean parameter.

  • raise_when_negative_prediction (bool, default = True) ‚Äì See raise_when_negative_prediction parameter.

  • raise_when_negative_error (bool, default=True) ‚Äì See raise_when_negative_error parameter.

  • training_set_frac (float) ‚Äì See training_set_frac parameter.

  • iters (int) ‚Äì See iters parameter.

  • common_indexes (Set) ‚Äì Indexes that are common for blocks and point support.

  • training_set_indexes (List[List]) ‚Äì List of lists of indexes used in a random sampling for a training set.

  • results (Dict) ‚Äì Results for each type of Block Kriging method.

run_tests() : Compares different types of Kriging, returns Dict with the mean root mean squared error of each

iteration.

run_tests()[source]#

Method compares ordinary, simple, area-to-area and centroid-based block Poisson Kriging.

pyinterpolate.pipelines.samples module#

The module contains functions that use public APIs to get data samples for experiments.

Authors#

  1. Sean Lim | @seanjunheng2

download_air_quality_poland(dataset: str) → DataFrame[source]#

Function downloads air quality data from Polish (Central Europe) stations. (EPSG:4326)

Parameters:

dataset (str) ‚Äì

The observed compound from the following list:

  • ‚ÄòCO‚Äô: carbon monoxide,

  • ‚ÄòSO2‚Äô: sulfur dioxide,

  • ‚ÄòPM2.5‚Äô: particulate matter with size <= 2.5 micrometers,

  • ‚ÄòPM10‚Äô: particulate matter with size <= 10 micrometers,

  • ‚ÄòNO2‚Äô: nitrogen dioxide,

  • ‚Äò03‚Äô: ozone,

  • ‚ÄòC6H6‚Äô: benzene.

Returns:

  • final_df (DataFrame) ‚Äì columns = [station_id, x, y, reading name]

  • ‚Äî‚Äî-
